block.p: Jacqueline May Lowey, a daughter of Representative Nita M. Lowey and Stephen Lowey of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday evening in East Hampton, N.Y., to David Kuperschmid, a son of Eleanor and Norman Kuperschmid of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at East Hampton Point, a restaurant.

The bride, 36, is keeping her name. She is a consultant in East Hampton on transportation and natural resources. Until July she was a deputy director of the National Park Service in Washington. She graduated from Swarthmore College. Her mother, a Democrat, represents the 18th Congressional District, which comprises parts of Westchester County, the Bronx and Queens. The bride's father is a founding partner in Lowey, Dannenberg, Bemporad & Selinger, a law firm in White Plains.

Jacqueline May Lowey, a daughter of Representative Nita M. Lowey and Stephen Lowey of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday evening in East Hampton, N.Y., to David Kuperschmid, a son of Eleanor and Norman Kuperschmid of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at East Hampton Point, a restaurant.

The bride, 36, is keeping her name. She is a consultant in East Hampton on transportation and natural resources. Until July she was a deputy director of the National Park Service in Washington. She graduated from Swarthmore College. Her mother, a Democrat, represents the 18th Congressional District, which comprises parts of Westchester County, the Bronx and Queens. The bride's father is a founding partner in Lowey, Dannenberg, Bemporad & Selinger, a law firm in White Plains.

The bridegroom, 45, owns ConsumerVision, a video marketing and distribution company in East Hampton. He graduated from the University of Rochester and received a master's degree in labor relations from Cornell University. His father retired as the president of the Harstan Chemical Corporation in Brooklyn.
